snippet.title: Two quantum computing tribes: University of Sydney v UNSW
snippet.content:
There are two great teams in Sydney exploring ways to build quantum computers.
Professor Michelle Simmons explains the operation of a new scanning tunnelling microscope to the Prime Minister, Malcolm Turnbull (right) and Minister for Science, Christopher Pyne (centre). Photo: Marcus Strom Leaders: Michelle Simmons, Andrew Dzurak, Andrea Morello, Sven Rogge Research team: 180 New investment: $25m from UNSW for lab extension; $26m from federal government's innovation agenda; Commonwealth Bank $10m; Telstra $10m Approach: UNSW as centre based on phosphorous qubits in silicon. Collaboration with other centres globally when needed. University of Sydney Centre for Engineered Quantum Systems
Professor David Reilly in his University of Sydney lab. Photo: Nick Moir Leaders: David Reilly, Stephen Bartlett, Andrew Doherty, Michael Biercuk, Steven Flammia. Research team: 72 New investment: $150m Nanoscience Hub launched this month, including $40m from federal government; ongoing collaboration and support from Microsoft's Station Q project and US government. Approaches: 1) Gallium arsenide qubit system; 2) Topological systems to encode and protect quantum information. Collaboration with University of Copenhagen, TU Delft and Microsoft integral to approach. 3) Ion trap qubits. THREE PATHS TO QUANTUM COMPUTING Phosphorus in silicon (UNSW) Pluses: Long coherence times of single spin qubits (when decoupled from magnetic noise) Minuses: Background electronic "charge noise" from impurities difficult to manage; single-atom architecture difficult to "scale up" to big computers Gallium arsenide (USyd) Pluses: Clean materials system with low background electronic charge noise Minuses: Susceptible to magnetic noise Ion trapped qubits (USyd) Pluses: Very long qubit coherence times (longer than silicon) Minuses: Very challenging to "scale up" to large numbers of qubit systems
The story first appeared on .
